params.text:
• Structure the Email
  • Dates and Times
  • Use Prepositions of Time

Professional Writing

Exchange Simple Information 1

Language in Action

Welcome back!

Today, we have 3 topics

1. Structure the Email: Learn the different parts of an email and how to organize them.

  2. Dates and Times: Discover how to write dates and times clearly in emails.

  3. Prepositions of Time: Practice using prepositions like "on," "in," and "at" to talk about time in emails.
Structure the Email: Key Points

Professional emails need the correct structure. 

Here are 4 tips to remember:
• Keep it short and informative. Briefly state the purpose of your email.
• This is the main message of your email. Keep it clear, concise, and easy to understand.
• End your email politely with "Thanks," "Best regards," or "Sincerely," followed by your name.

params.textField:
*Subject*: Meeting Reminder - Sales Report
Hi Sarah, *(Greeting)*
I hope this email finds you well. *(Introduction)*
This email is a friendly reminder about our meeting tomorrow at 10:00 am. We will be discussing the sales report for last month. *(Body)*
Please let me know if you have any questions in advance. *(Body)*
Thanks, *(Sign Off)*
David

params.textField:
Subject: Deadline Reminder - Project Proposal
Hi Maria,
This *email* is a reminder that the deadline for submitting the project proposal is coming up soon. The final *proposals* are due on *Friday*, August *4th*.
Please let me know if you have any questions *before* Thursday.
Thanks,
David

params.text: Choose the BEST answer for each question:
Use Prepositions of Time: Key Points

Prepositions of time help us understand when something happens in an email.

Here's a quick guide to some common ones:

Use "in" for months, seasons, and years.

  • Example: The report is due in November. (Month)
  • Example: We will have a company picnic in the summer. (Season)

Use "at" for specific times of day.

  • Example: The meeting starts at 9:00 am. (Time of day)

Use "on" for days of the week and specific dates.

  • Example: The deadline is on Friday, August 4th. (Specific date)
  • Example: We will be closed on Monday for Labor Day. (Day of the week)

Use no preposition for general time expressions like "today," "tomorrow," "yesterday," "night," or "morning."

  • Example: I will be out of the office tomorrow. (No preposition for "tomorrow")
  • Example: We can discuss this further later. (No preposition for "later")

params.textField:
Hi Sarah,
This email is a reminder about our meeting *on* Wednesday *at* 10:00 am. We will be reviewing the sales report for *last month*.
*In* advance of the meeting, could you please send me the *report*?
Thanks,
David

params.text: Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: An email to a client should start with a greeting like:
Question 2 of 6: The body of the email contains:
answers:
The main message of your email 

Your signature 

The date of the email

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: We use the word "on" to talk about:
answers:
Days of the week 

Months

Specific times of day

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: The deadline for the project is in August. Which word can we use if the deadline is a specific date, like August 10th?
Question 5 of 6: The meeting starts at 9:00 am. "At" is used for:
answers:
Specific times of day 

Days of the week 

Months

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: I will be out of the office tomorrow. We don't use a preposition with:
answers:
Words like "tomorrow" or "today" 

Specific dates 

Days of the week
